job_title: Donor Relationship Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Relatively laid back work environment. Culture of people was reasonably fun to be around.
cons: This was by far the worst place I worked during my tenure in fundraising. Leadership was constantly changing, there were no set goals or responsibilities within our roles, and management was hindered by poor top level and board planning.

pros: It's a very collegial environment and you learn a lot.
cons: No real cons. The compensation can be a little low, but it's offset by the fact that the work is interesting.

pros: It was one of the most collegial work environments I've experienced.
cons: Nothing really. I guess there are some slow parts of the year.

review_title: Excellent place to gain early-career experience
job_title: Ronald Reagan Fellow in Phoenix, AZ
pros: As a Ronald Reagan Fellow (their name for intern), you are able to learn a lot about the day to day workings of a think tank. Generally a very open workplace environment, most everyone is very friendly. Internship is paid, which is somewhat rare in this field. Good work/life balance, nice office facilities. GWI likes to hire qualified former interns, so if you do a good job it could possibly lead to full time employment.
cons: More micromanaging from upper-level management than there probably should be, although this varies by department. Also, interns are responsible for a fair amount of cleaning/upkeep/setups in the office (not a big deal, but felt the need to mention it nonetheless).

pros: Good internship getting a look into the Think Tank world. Has a pretty hefty internship program outside of actual work, including some really good readings and discussions. Everyone that I interacted with was really friendly and always ready to discuss anything.
cons: They seem to experience some high turnover, something that I have observed happens to most organizations in the Think Tank world. A lot of the people who I worked with there were fairly new to the organization, and only a year later many of them have moved on to jobs with different organizations.

pros: Great team, united by an awesome new CEO and leadership team who will help get the org back on track, coalescing around the cause-driven mission.
cons: The former CEO was a nightmare who used the organization as her personal bank account/vanity project/etc. Unfortunately, the org really suffered during her tenure and they lost a lot of great staff.

pros: This is the company I choose to work since it has a positive feedback in my community and when I started to work I can see that company's is great in what they do and has good work ethics.
cons: As company as big as this, they need to hire more people to help them out.

pros:
-Prestigious think-tank (Top-10 Nationally) arguably the best state-level think tank in the nation
-Very active & dynamic group of indiviuals who cover both economic & legal research, solid variety available
cons:
-Poor communication skills from management staff
-Very mundane work for interns
-Poor pay for the amount of hours worked

pros: Passionate group of liberty fighters focused on success and regularly achieving it.
cons: Lots of turnover in the past, leading to a very short tenure among current staff.

pros: This is a good company to work for
cons: It could be a great company to work for

pros: Great staff, good management, interesting work.
Best place to showcase my ability and great people. This is one of the best company for me.
cons: Need more employees since the company is growing

pros: Lots of autonomy, highly influential institute, plenty of resources to get the job done right
cons: Short staffed and in need of more stable employees

pros: Enjoyable "team" atmosphere and meaningful, impactful work.
cons: Employees outside the legal department are not too friendly
